title: 110_hr1216
content: The "Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act of 2007" or the "K.T. Safety Act of 2007" mandates the Secretary of Transportation to consider implementing safety standards for power windows on motor vehicles to prevent accidents involving children and others. If deemed reasonable, practicable, and appropriate, these standards must be prescribed within 30 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will report to Congress if no additional safety standards are deemed feasible, and will provide information to the public on vehicles with power windows that automatically reverse when obstructed. Additionally, within 12 months, a rulemaking will be initiated to expand rearward visibility in vehicles to enhance driver awareness and reduce accidents. The Secretary will establish safety standards for motor vehicles to improve rearward visibility, reducing accidents involving small children and disabled persons. Compliance with the standards must be achieved within 48 months of the final rule issuance. The Secretary will prioritize phasing in rearward visibility safety standards for different types of motor vehicles based on backing incident data. Motor vehicles with automatic transmission manufactured after September 1, 2010, must have a system that requires the brake to be depressed before shifting out of "park". The Secretary will enforce safety standards for motor vehicles with automatic transmissions that do not comply with shifting requirements out of "park". Manufacturers must submit noncompliant vehicle information annually, and the Secretary will publish this information for public access. The Act defines a motor vehicle as per section 30102(a)(6) of title 49, excluding motorcycles, trailers, and vehicles over 10,000 pounds. The Secretary will establish a database of injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The Act mandates the establishment of a database for injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles. It includes information on injuries, deaths, vehicle details, and other relevant variables. The Secretary must make this database available to the public. Additionally, within 9 months of the Act's enactment, the Secretary must provide child safety information through an existing or new consumer program. The Act mandates a new consumer information program on child safety, addressing various risks to children. The Secretary must use collected data to establish program priorities and make information available to the public. If deadlines cannot be met, new deadlines must be established and communicated to relevant committees. The Senate is informing about new deadlines and reasons for not meeting the deadlines specified under the Act.
